str:ConceptScheme.com:Name: Master Domain Concepts
str:ConceptScheme.com:Description: Standardized definitions for data elements specific to particular domains or subject areas. This includes concepts and attributes related to macroeconomics, finance, socio-demographics, and other specialized fields.

str:Concept.com:Name: Accounting Entry
str:Concept.com:Description: A classification that identifies whether a transaction represents a use of resources, a source of funds, an asset, a liability, or a change in equity.

str:Concept.com:Name: Commodity
str:Concept.com:Description: Comprehensive list of all the different commodity codes used in IMF.

str:Concept.com:Name: Sector
str:Concept.com:Description: A classification of economic entities based on their primary function and economic behavior, such as households, corporations, government, or non-profit institutions.

str:Concept.com:Name: Counterpart Sector
str:Concept.com:Description: In the context of a specific transaction or economic flow, the counterpart sector refers to the institutional sector on the opposite side of the transaction.

str:Concept.com:Name: Exchange Rate
str:Concept.com:Description: Represents a set of codes identifying the exchange rate between two currencies. An exchange rate indicates how much of one currency is needed to buy one unit of another currency. It is derived by comparing the value of one currency to another, often influenced by economic factors like interest rates, inflation, and government policy. This codelist includes various exchange rate calculations, such as period averages, pre-Euro rates, and those involving Special Drawing Rights (SDRs).

str:Concept.com:Name: Flow or stock entry
str:Concept.com:Description: A classification that indicates whether a data point represents a flow (a quantity measured over a period of time) or a stock (a quantity measured at a specific point in time).

str:Concept.com:Name: Functional category
str:Concept.com:Description: A classification used to categorize investments based on their purpose or function, such as equity investments, debt investments, or other investments.

str:Concept.com:Name: GFS Stocks, Transactions, Other Flows
str:Concept.com:Description: A classification of data items used in the Government Finance Statistics (GFS) framework, distinguishing between stocks (levels at a point in time), transactions (changes over a period), and other flows.

str:Concept.com:Name: Index type
str:Concept.com:Description: Type of index prices.

str:Concept.com:Name: Interest Rate types, Terms and Conditions
str:Concept.com:Description: A classification of interest rates based on their type (fixed or floating), terms (maturity), and other conditions (e.g., collateralization, reference rates).

str:Concept.com:Name: Instrument and Assets Classification
str:Concept.com:Description: Because of the symmetry of financial assets and liabilities, the term ‘instrument’ is used to relate to both the asset and the liability aspect of financial transactions, other flows and financial balance sheets. (Source: Handbook of National Accounting, 2013)

str:Concept.com:Name: International Accounts Item
str:Concept.com:Description: A classification of transactions in the balance of payments, such as trade in goods, services, income, and financial flows.

str:Concept.com:Name: Macroeconomic and Financial Accounts
str:Concept.com:Description: A framework for organizing macroeconomic and financial data into a set of integrated accounts and tables that provide a comprehensive overview of an economy.

str:Concept.com:Name: Maturity of Financial Instrument
str:Concept.com:Description: A classification of financial instruments based on their remaining time to maturity or expiration.

str:Concept.com:Name: Monetary and Financial Instruments
str:Concept.com:Description: A classification of financial instruments used in monetary and financial statistics, including currency, deposits, loans, securities, and derivatives.

str:Concept.com:Name: Stocks, Transactions, Other Flows
str:Concept.com:Description: A classification of data items used in the System of National Accounts (SNA) framework, distinguishing between stocks (levels at a point in time), transactions (changes over a period), and other flows.

str:Concept.com:Name: Prices
str:Concept.com:Description: Represents different types of prices or price adjustments, including those that have been adjusted for inflation (real or constant prices) and those that have not (nominal or current prices). It also includes various methods for adjusting prices for inflation, such as using deflators or converting to a constant base period.

str:Concept.com:Name: Statistical Measures
str:Concept.com:Description: Describe characteristics of a group of data. They summarize the distribution, central tendency, or spread of multiple values.

str:Concept.com:Name: Trade flow
str:Concept.com:Description: Data related to the movement of goods and services between countries, including exports and imports.

str:Concept.com:Name: Valuation
str:Concept.com:Description: Valuation refers to the rules and conventions used for recording monetary flows and stocks in macroeconomic statistics. Standard national accounts valuations include the basic price (what the seller receives) and the purchaser's price (what the purchaser pays). The purchaser's price is the basic price, plus taxes less subsidies on products, plus invoiced transportation and insurance services, plus distribution margin. International trade in goods considers the free on board (fob) price and cost-insurance-freight price, among others. Other valuation types include prices used in financial markets (e.g., buy and sell prices).

str:Concept.com:Name: Social Concepts
str:Concept.com:Description: A broad category encompassing various social indicators, such as tourism and labor concepts.

str:Concept.com:Name: COFOG
str:Concept.com:Description: The Classification of the Functions of Government, a standardized system for classifying government expenditures by purpose.

str:Concept.com:Name: Expenditure Category
str:Concept.com:Description: The Classification of Individual Consumption According to Purpose (COICOP) 1999 is a standardized classification system developed by the United Nations Statistics Division to categorize household consumption expenditures by purpose. It includes 14 divisions, 47 groups, and 117 classes.

str:Concept.com:Name: Expenditure Category (COICOP 2018)
str:Concept.com:Description: The Classification of Individual Consumption According to Purpose (COICOP) 2018 is an updated and expanded version of the COICOP classification system, designed to better reflect the evolving consumption patterns of the 21st century. It includes 14 divisions, 50 groups, 153 classes, and 449 subclasses.
